Description: Part of a jar-seal: of light brown clay, bearing an impressed inscription showing two lines of the repeated serekh of Djer. On the other side of the seal is a different inscription, belonging to the official Hemaka. The surface of the clay is hard and secure, but the inscriptions are rather worn.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pls.XV, 107; XVI, 123; H. R. Hall, 'Catalogue of Egyptian scarabs etc. in the British Museum: Volume 1 : Royal scarabs' (London, 1913), 288, no.2 759; P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit III (Wiesbaden, 1964), pls. 15, abb.30A; 20, abb. 43; see also vols. I, 76 and II, 737, n. 330; 1096, 1099; B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' V (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 78.
Bibliographic references: Hall 1913 / Catalogue of Egyptian scarabs, etc. in the British Museum (2759)
